sentences.sentence: It was now the eighth day since I had had my accident in the desert, and I had listened to the story of the merchant( 商人 ) as I was drinking the last drop of my water supply.
“Ah,” I said to the little prince, “these memories of yours are very charming( 有吸引力的 ); but I have not yet succeeded in repairing my plane; I have nothing more to drink;
and I, too, should be very happy if I could walk at my leisure( 空闲时 ) toward a spring of fresh water!”
“My friend the fox—” the little prince said to me.
“My dear little man, this is no longer a matter that has anything to do with the fox!”
“Why not?”
“Because I am about to die of thirst . . .”
He did not follow my reasoning, and he answered me:
“It is a good thing to have had a friend, even if one is about to die. I, for instance, am very glad to have had a fox as a friend . . .”
“He has no way of guessing the danger,” I said to myself. “He has never been hungry or thirsty. A little sunshine is all he needs . . .”
But he looked at me steadily, and replied to my thought:
“I am thirsty, too. Let us look for a well( 井 ) . . .”
I made a gesture of weariness( 疲倦 ).
It is absurd( 荒唐的 ) to look for a well( 井 ), at random( 随意地 ), in the immensity( 浩瀚 ) of the desert.
But nevertheless we started walking.
When we had trudged( 艰难地走 ) along for several hours, in silence, the darkness fell, and the stars began to come out.
Thirst had made me a little feverish, and I looked at them as if I were in a dream.
The little prince’s last words came reeling( 眩晕 ) back into my memory.
“Then you are thirsty, too?” I demanded.
But he did not reply to my question.
He merely said to me:
“Water may also be good for the heart . . .”
I did not understand this answer, but I said nothing.
I knew very well that it was impossible to cross-examine him.
He was tired.
He sat down.
I sat down beside him.
And, after a little silence, he spoke again:
“The stars are beautiful, because of a flower that cannot be seen.”
I replied, “Yes, that is so.”
And, without saying anything more, I looked across the ridges( 脊 ) of sand that were stretched out( 延伸 ) before us in the moonlight.
“The desert is beautiful,” the little prince added.
And that was true.
I have always loved the desert.
One sits down on a desert sand dune( 沙丘 ), sees nothing, hears nothing.
Yet through the silence something throbs( 颤动 ), and gleams( 发光 ) . . .
“What makes the desert beautiful,” said the little prince, “is that somewhere it hides a well( 井 ) . . .”
I was astonished( 被震惊 ) by a sudden understanding of that mysterious radiation( 光芒 ) of the sands.
When I was a little boy I lived in an old house, and legend( 传说 ) told us that a treasure was buried there.
To be sure, no one had ever known how to find it; perhaps no one had ever even looked for it.
But it cast an enchantment( 魔法 ) over that house.
My home was hiding a secret in the depths of its heart . . .
“Yes,” I said to the little prince. “The house, the stars, the desert—what gives them their beauty is something that is invisible( 看不见的 )!”
“I am glad,” he said, “that you agree with my fox.”
As the little prince  dropped off( 打瞌睡 )  to sleep, I took him in my arms and set out walking once more.
I felt deeply moved, and stirred( 激动的 ).
It seemed to me that I was carrying a very fragile( 脆弱的 ) treasure.
It seemed to me, even, that there was nothing more fragile( 脆弱的 ) on all Earth.
In the moonlight I looked at his pale forehead, his closed eyes, his locks of( 一缕缕 ) hair that trembled( 飘动 ) in the wind,
and I said to myself: “What I see here is nothing but a shell( 外表 ). What is most important is invisible( 看不见的 ) . . .”
As his lips opened slightly with the suspicion of( 一丝 ) a half-smile, I said to myself, again:
“What moves me so deeply, about this little prince who is sleeping here, is his loyalty( 忠诚 ) to a flower
—the image of a rose that shines through his whole being like the flame of a lamp, even when he is asleep . . .”
And I felt him to be more fragile( 脆弱的 ) still. I felt the need of protecting him, as if he himself were a flame that might be extinguished( 熄灭 ) by a little puff( 一阵 ) of wind . . .
And, as I walked on so, I found the well( 井 ), at daybreak( 黎明 ).
“Men,” said the little prince, “set out on their way in express trains( 特快列车 ), but they do not know what they are looking for.
Then they rush about( 奔波 ), and get excited, and turn round and round . . .”
And he added:
“It is not worth the trouble . . .”
The well( 井 ) that we had come to was not like the wells( 井 ) of the Sahara( 撒哈拉，地名 ).
The wells( 井 ) of the Sahara( 撒哈拉，地名 ) are mere holes dug in the sand.
This one was like a well( 井 ) in a village. But there was no village here, and I thought I must be dreaming . . .
“It is strange,” I said to the little prince. “Everything is ready for use: the pulley( 滑轮 ), the bucket( 桶 ), the rope . . .”
He laughed, touched the rope, and set the pulley( 滑轮 ) to working.
And the pulley( 滑轮 ) moaned( 发出呜咽声 ), like an old weathervane( 风向标 ) which the wind has long since forgotten.
“Do you hear?” said the little prince. “We have wakened the well( 井 ), and it is singing . . .”
I did not want him to tire himself with the rope.
“Leave it to me,” I said. “It is too heavy for you.”
I hoisted( 升起 ) the bucket( 桶 ) slowly to the edge of the well( 井 ) and set it there— happy, tired as I was, over my achievement.
The song of the pulley( 滑轮 ) was still in my ears, and I could see the sunlight shimmer( 闪烁 ) in the still trembling( 潺潺的 ) water.
“I am thirsty for( 需要 ) this water,” said the little prince. “Give me some of it to drink . . .”
And I understood what he had been looking for.

article_info.previous: 小王子驯化了狐狸，但后来他又离开了狐狸。在之后的旅程中，他遇到了一位扳道工和一位销售止渴药片的商人。
article_info.share_words: “What makes the desert beautiful,” said the little prince, “is that somewhere it hides a well . . .”

question.cn: 在事故后的第八天，"我"还有多少水？
question.en: How much water did "I" have on the eighth day after the accident?

analysis: 原文提到：It was now the eighth day since I had had my accident in the desert, and I had listened to the story of the merchant as I was drinking the last drop of my water supply. 所以答案为B。

question.cn: 根据小王子的说法，什么使得沙漠美丽？
question.en: According to the little prince, what made the desert beautiful?

options.en: A flower that could not be seen.
A well that was hidden in the desert.

analysis: 原文提到：“What makes the desert beautiful,” said the little prince, “is that somewhere it hides a well . . .”所以答案为C。

question.cn: 小王子和“我”什么时候找到了井？
question.en: When did the little prince and "I" found the well?

analysis: 原文提到：And, as I walked on so, I found the well, at daybreak. 所以答案为B。
